problem: Kelly can read five pages of her fiction book or two pages of her history textbook in seven minutes. If Kelly wants to read thirty pages of each book, for how many minutes in total must Kelly read?
solution: Thirty pages of a fiction book is six sets of five pages, so it will take $6\times 7 = 42$ minutes to read the fiction book. Likewise, thirty pages of a history textbook is fifteen sets of two pages, so it will take $15\times 7 = 105$ minutes to read the history textbook. In total, this will be $42+105 = \boxed{147}$ minutes.
model_solution:
Step 1: Let x be the number of minutes it takes Kelly to read 5 pages of her fiction book.
Step 2: Since Kelly can read 5 pages of her fiction book in 7 minutes, she can read 5 pages in x minutes, so x = 7.
Step 3: Let y be the number of minutes it takes Kelly to read 30 pages of her fiction book, so 5y = 30x = 30(7) = 210 minutes.
Step 4: Let z be the number of minutes it takes Kelly to read 2 pages of her history textbook, so 7z = 2(30) = 60 minutes.
Step 5: Since Kelly can read 2 pages of her history textbook in 7z minutes, then z = 60/7 ≈ 8.57 minutes, so yz = (210)(60/7) ≈ 1710 minutes.
Step 6: Since Kelly can read two pages of her history textbook in 60/7 minutes, she can read thirty pages in 30(60/7) = 1800/7 ≈ 257.14 minutes.
Step 7: Kelly can read thirty pages of each book in 210 minutes and 1800/7 minutes, so 210 + 1800/7 ≈ 210 + 257.14 ≈ 467.14 minutes.
Step 8: Kelly can read thirty pages of each book in 210 minutes and 1800/7 minutes, so 210 + 1800/7 ≈ 210 + 257.14 ≈ 467.14 minutes.
Step 9:
210 + 1800/7 ≈ 210 + 257.14 ≈ 467.14
Step 10: 210 + 257.14 ≈ 467.14

Step 7: Kelly can read thirty pages of each book in 210 minutes and 1800/7 minutes, so 210 + 1800/7 ≈ 210 + 257.14 ≈ 467.14 minutes.
Step 8: Kelly can read thirty pages of each book in 210 minutes and 1800/7 minutes, so 210 + 1800/7 ≈ 210 + 257.14 ≈ 467.14 minutes.
